body.p:
Louisville Ky June 30th 1862
Honl B. McGagoffin
Dear Sir

Enclosed I send you a petition of John Nelsen and one of his neighbors praying you to remit the fine of $20 or ten days imprisonment, shown by copy of proceeding accompaning the petition I earnestly desire you to remit this fine a great outrage has been inflicted on this old man He was taken and off from home; the officer refused to summon his witnesses by whom he could have shown that he did nothing wrong

Esqr T Conn who was at the trial & signs the petition says Esqr Conner who tried the case did very wrong. Nelsen after the trial made application for a new trial but Conner refused him, telling him to take an appeal to the County Court

Nelson is charged with Southern right proclivities and therefore the unbecoming haste
and prejudice I have taken pains to inform myself in relation to this trial and am satisfied that Nelsen did nothing more than he should have done. I saw his wife a day or two after the occurance and her face was very much bruised from the blows Gilliland gave her. You will do an act of Justice by remitting the fine & imprisonment.
